text.div:
HSPC Weight Meas Method Device

The set of codes that describe the methods or devices used to measure an individual's weight.

Copyright Statement: Intermountain Healthcare

This code system http://hl7.org/fhir/observation-hspc-weightMeasMethodDevice defines the following codes:

Code Display Definition
1964 Bed scale A scale that measures the weight of a patient by measuring the total mass of a bed and patient, then subtracts the known mass of the bed.
2007 Chair scale A scale that measures the weight of a patient by measuring the total mass of a chair and patient, then subtracts the known mass of the chair.
2139 Sling scale A scale for patients that are unable to stand, patients sit in a sling attached to a boom.
2142 Standing scale A scale upon which an individual will stand to measure body weight
2180 Weight, lean; immersion A measurement of lean body weight made by immersing an individual in water and then measuring the mass of the displacement.
2181 Weight, lean; skin fold A measurement of lean body weight made by measuring the thickness of a fold of skin.
2185 Weight, percentile A body weight based on other measurements plotted on a percentile chart.
50550851 Infant Scale A scale designed for use with infants only
521443011 Broselow tape A measuring tape created to relate a child's height, as measured by the tape to the child's weight

name: HSPC Weight Meas Method Device
description: The set of codes that describe the methods or devices used to measure an individual's weight.

concept.definition: A scale that measures the weight of a patient by measuring the total mass of a bed and patient, then subtracts the known mass of the bed.

A scale for patients that are unable to stand, patients sit in a sling attached to a boom.
A scale upon which an individual will stand to measure body weight
A measurement of lean body weight made by immersing an individual in water and then measuring the mass of the displacement.
A measurement of lean body weight made by measuring the thickness of a fold of skin.
A body weight based on other measurements plotted on a percentile chart.
A scale designed for use with infants only
A measuring tape created to relate a child's height, as measured by the tape to the child's weight
